page.title: 17FRISKNEY SCHOOL IN THE PAST
page.content: The present school was founded as a National School in 1860. There had been a school since 1815. The Schoolmaster and his wife were paid Â£52 p.a. from the Church "poor land" rents. The new school cost Â£760 of which Â£412 was raised by public subscription and the land was given by the Vicar the Rev. Booth. Of the 2 rooms,the large one was divided by a partition. There were 7 standards of at least 40 children each with 3 teachers and 1 pupil teacher. The children sat at long wooden desks with 8 to 10 at each desk. There was no sanitation and heating was by open fires or tortoise stoves. In 1960 the school was extensively modernised and extended with 7 classrooms, offices inside toilets and a canteen. In 1959 children transferred at 11 years to secondary modern or grammar schools.
